description: Functions designed to manipulate paths in a cross-platform manner.

functions.name: basename
functions.description: Return the final component of a path

returns.description: The final component of path. This is everything after the last `/` (under Unix) or `\` (under Windows).

functions.name: dirname
functions.description: Return the directory part of the path.

returns.description: Everything before the last `/` (under Unix) or `\` (under Windows). If the path contains no directory, return `.`

functions.name: join
functions.description: Join path components. This file is the recommended manner of getting the path of a file or a subdirectory contained in a directory.

parameters.name: subpath
parameters.description: path component that must be appended to path

parameters.name: subpath2
parameters.description: path component that must be appended to path

parameters.name: subpath3
parameters.description: path component that must be appended to path

parameters.name: subpath4
parameters.description: path component that must be appended to path

returns.description: The result of concatenaging the paths. If any of the subpaths is absolute, anything before this subpath is ignored. The path may not be normalized.

functions.name: normalize
functions.description: Normalize a path by removing unneeded ., .., /, .

returns.description: A path equivalent to path, but in which needless occurrences of `.`, `..`, `/` and `\` have been removed.

functions.name: split
functions.description: Split a path into its components

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: A path. Generally, it should be normalized

absolute.description: true if path is absolute, false otherwise

components.description: An array containing the components that define path

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Request to mount specific directory as a virtual FileSystem.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: file url to open descriptor for.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: The opening mode for the file

read.description: If true, the file will be opened for reading

write.description: If true, the file will be opened for writing.

truncate.description: If true, the file will be opened for writing. If the file does not exist, it will be created. If the file exists, its contents will be removed. Cannot be used with `create`.

create.description: If true, file will be opened for writing. The file must not exist. If the file already exists, throw an error. Cannot be used with truncate or existing.

existing.description: If true, the file must already exist. If the file does not exist, throw an error. Cannot be used with create.

append.description: If true, the file will be opened for appending.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: Platform-specific options for opening the file. For advanced users only. Most users will never have need of these options.

unixFlags.description: (ignored under non-Unix platforms) If specified, file opening flags, as per libc function open. If unspecified, build these flags from the contents of mode.

unixMode.description: (ignored under non-Unix platforms) If specified, file creation mode, as per libc function open. If unspecified, files are created with a default mode of 0600 (file is private to the user, the user can read and write).

winShare.description: (ignored under non-Windows platforms) If specified, a sharing policy, as per Windows function CreateFile. If unspecified, files are opened with a default sharing policy (file is not protected against being read/written/removed by another process or another use in the same process).

winSecurity.description: (ignored under non-Windows platforms) If specified, a security policy, as per Windows function CreateFile. If unspecified, no security attributes

winAccess.description: (ignored under non-Windows platforms) If specified, access mode, as per Windows function CreateFile. This also requires option winDisposition and this replaces argument mode. If unspecified, value is built from mode.

winDisposition.description: (ignored under non-Windows platforms) If specified, disposition mode, as per Windows function CreateFile. This also requires option winAccess and this replaces argument mode. If unspecified, value is built from mode.
